text:
Today's vehicles emit only about 1% of the pollution than they did in the 1960s, and new innovations continue to improve those engines' efficiency and cleanliness.

And as for that electric car: The energy doesn't come from nowhere. Cars are charged from the nation's electrical grid, which means that they're only as "clean" as America's mix of power sources. Those are getting cleaner, but we still generate power mainly by burning fossil fuels: natural gas is our biggest source of electricity, and is projected to increase. And coal, while still declining, will remain the second largest source of electricity for some time. (Third is nuclear power, which doesn't generate emissions but has other byproducts that worry some environmentalists.) Even with large increases in wind and solar generation, the EIA projects that the nation's electric generating mix will be just 30% renewable by 2030. Based on that forecast, if the EIA's projected number of electric vehicles were replaced with new internal combustion vehicles, air pollution would actually decreaseand this holds true even if you include the emissions from oil refineries that manufacture gasoline.

There is the concern of nickel mining for the batteries. A 2009 study published in PLOS One concluded that the global warming potential of mining and processing nickel was the eighth highest of 63 metals over the previous year. Not to mention the other harmful chemicals emmited into the air though the process.

Lithium is a tedious process too that requires evaporation pools which release hydrochloric acid and other harmful chemicals into the air, creating a impact on the groundwater around the plants, affecting both humans and the environment around them. 100,000 gallons of fresh water is required to make one tonne of lithium for batteries. There have been plenty of accidents where those pools have leaked into local waterways, affecting those ecosystems even over 100 miles from the facility. There is also a lot of waste leftover after the final product is completed, and very little of it is being recycled.

Cobalt is another essential metal for batteries, and is only found in the Democratic Republic of Congo and central Africa. The people there are the ones who mine it because it's the only source of income. Many of them work by hand. They don't use power tools. They don't wear face masks and often no gloves. There are huge health risks for those people .

If that's not enough, have you ever asked yourself : "where do all these batteries go after they are no longer used?" As I said before very little of it gets recycled, so they end up in landfills, leak out and impact our impact all around the world outside of where the batteries go from start to landfill.

Basically, the need for emissions testing doesn't really seem necessary, and could be used to fund the county's infrastructure instead. Any cars of concern are mainly from other counties or states that drive through the county.

I am writing to support the No-Action Alternative for the Draft Environmental Impact Statement on the proposed Alaska Roadless Rule, Alternative #1. I support keeping the current Roadless Rule protections in place and intact for the Tongass National Forest. Trumps plan is yet another attack from the Trump administration on Indigenous rights. Alaskan Native communities -- including the Tlingit, Haida, and Tsimshian peoples -- have depended on the Tongass Rainforest for millennia. It is the backbone to their culture, traditions, and communities -- we simply cannot let it disappear.

The Tongass contains some of the largest intact old-growth temperate rainforest in the world, and its value in providing clean water for fish and wildlife habitat is essential to the economic and ecological health of Southeast Alaska. I urge you to keep the federal Roadless Rule intact and current protections in place for national forests in Alaska.

In addition, I strongly object to your plans to reduce and remove protections from our national forests roadless areas. The Roadless Rule is one of the smartest and most popular land management policies the Federal Government has ever adopted. Not only does it preserve some of Americas best fish and wildlife habitat, but it also saves untold millions of taxpayer dollars that might otherwise be spent to subsidize money-losing timber sales. The value of the Roadless Rule in preventing environmentally damaging and economically wasteful road-building and logging is particularly relevant in the Tongass, where logging costs vastly exceed timber revenues and require unconscionable taxpayer subsidies.

Regards,
Patricia Medina
docAbstract: The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) is proposing to exempt the Tongass National Forest from the 2001 Roadless Area Conservation Rule, which prohibits tree harvest and road construction/reconstruction within inventoried roadless areas with certain limited exceptions. In addition, the proposed rule would provide an administrative procedure for correcting and modifying inventoried roadless area boundaries on the Chugach National Forest. The USDA invites written comments on the proposed rule and the draft environmental impact statement (DEIS). The proposed rule would not directly authorize any ground-disturbing activities. Substantive comments received during the comment period will be considered in developing the final rule and final environmental impact statement (FEIS). The final rule will be published in the Federal Register.

I am writing to support the No-Action Alternative for the Draft Environmental Impact Statement on the proposed Alaska Roadless Rule, Alternative #1. I support keeping the current Roadless Rule protections in place and intact for the Tongass National Forest. Donald Trumps plan is yet another attack from the Trump administration on Indigenous rights. Alaskan Native communities -- including the Tlingit, Haida, and Tsimshian peoples -- have depended on the Tongass Rainforest for millennia. It is the backbone to their culture, traditions, and communities -- we simply cannot let it disappear.

The Tongass contains some of the largest intact old-growth temperate rainforest in the world, and its value in providing clean water for fish and wildlife habitat is essential to the economic and ecological health of Southeast Alaska. I urge you to keep the federal Roadless Rule intact and current protections in place for national forests in Alaska.

In addition, I strongly object to your plans to reduce and remove protections from our national forests roadless areas. The Roadless Rule is one of the smartest and most popular land management policies the Federal Government has ever adopted. Not only does it preserve some of Americas best fish and wildlife habitat, but it also saves untold millions of taxpayer dollars that might otherwise be spent to subsidize money-losing timber sales. The value of the Roadless Rule in preventing environmentally damaging and economically wasteful road-building and logging is particularly relevant in the Tongass, where logging costs vastly exceed timber revenues and require unconscionable taxpayer subsidies.

Regards,
David Mckee
docAbstract: The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) is proposing to exempt the Tongass National Forest from the 2001 Roadless Area Conservation Rule, which prohibits tree harvest and road construction/reconstruction within inventoried roadless areas with certain limited exceptions. In addition, the proposed rule would provide an administrative procedure for correcting and modifying inventoried roadless area boundaries on the Chugach National Forest. The USDA invites written comments on the proposed rule and the draft environmental impact statement (DEIS). The proposed rule would not directly authorize any ground-disturbing activities. Substantive comments received during the comment period will be considered in developing the final rule and final environmental impact statement (FEIS). The final rule will be published in the Federal Register.

Bill

***ADD PERSONAL MESSAGE about why discrimination has no place in HHS programs**

My name is Paul Gaffney and Im from Albuquerque, New Mexico. Im writing in regard to the published Health and Human Services Grants Regulation (RIN 0991-AC16).

It is absolutely unConstitutional to allow Federal funds to support religious discrimination. Separation of Church and State is paramount to the foundation of this country. Giving funds to organisations that use their religious beliefs to discriminate is unAmerican and outright illegal.

Stop breaking the law.

Sincerely,

Paul Gaffney

My name is Danielle Romano and Im from Lakeport, CA. Im writing in regard to the published Health and Human Services Grants Regulation (RIN 0991-AC16).

This country is filled with beautiful people, patriots who defend this county. Please defend these people. The LBGTQ+, the mothers in HIV prevention programs, minoritiesthey are just like you. American people who deserve all the things Federal Programs offer. The beauty of this country is that people get to be themselves and live as free American citizens regardless if they agree with us or not. Dont take that away. This country deserves better, the people deserve better. Your job is to protect and advocate for the people, ALL of them. Because that is what they are, they are people. They are daughters, and husbands, and teachers and firefighters. They are deserving of basic rights granted to others. They are us and we are them. Do not discriminate. This is a country for and BY the people. Dont do this. History will remember you. Why not be a the world leader in acceptance? Why not?

My name is Lauren Sleezer and Im from Seattle, WA Im writing in regard to the published Health and Human Services Grants Regulation (RIN 0991-AC16).

The separation of church and state is a fundamental foundation to our democracy. By allowing religion to dictate who does/doesnt receive tax-funded services, we violate our Founding Fathers vision. Religious freedom at the expense of others right to live safely is not freedom at all - but objective discrimination. Please reverse this regulation immediately.

My name is Ezra Levinson and Im from Kailua, Hawaii. Im writing in regard to the published Health and Human Services Grants Regulation (RIN 0091-AC16).

The Department of Health and Human Services has a constitutional and moral mandate to protect all American citizens. Allowing discrimination in a taxpayer-funded program will strip me and hundreds of thousands of people like me of protections that I need in order to be on an equal footing with everyone else in America. Please dont do this to me.

My name is Caitlin Brown and Im from Highlands Ranch, Colorado. Im writing in regard to the published Health and Human Services Grants Regulation (RIN 0991-AC16).

RELIGION SHOULD HAVE NOTHING TO DO WITH GOVERNMENT POLICY, REGULATIONS, OR PROGRAMS. DISCRIMINATION HAS NO PLACE IN OUR COUNTRY, AND WE THE PEOPLE WILL NOT STAND FOR IT. HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES SERVE ALL HUMANS, NO MATTER THEIR COLOR, THEIR ORIENTATION, THEIR RELIGION, ANYTHING. I think I have made myself clear.

I am writing to support the No-Action Alternative for the Draft Environmental Impact Statement on the proposed Alaska Roadless Rule, Alternative #1. I support keeping the current Roadless Rule protections in place and intact for the Tongass National Forest. Trumps plan is yet another attack from the Trump administration on Indigenous rights. Alaskan Native communities -- including the Tlingit, Haida, and Tsimshian peoples -- have depended on the Tongass Rainforest for millennia. It is the backbone to their culture, traditions, and communities -- we simply cannot let it disappear.

The Tongass contains some of the largest intact old-growth temperate rainforest in the world, and its value in providing clean water for fish and wildlife habitat is essential to the economic and ecological health of Southeast Alaska. I urge you to keep the federal Roadless Rule intact and current protections in place for national forests in Alaska.

In addition, I strongly object to your plans to reduce and remove protections from our national forests roadless areas. The Roadless Rule is one of the smartest and most popular land management policies the Federal Government has ever adopted. Not only does it preserve some of Americas best fish and wildlife habitat, but it also saves untold millions of taxpayer dollars that might otherwise be spent to subsidize money-losing timber sales. The value of the Roadless Rule in preventing environmentally damaging and economically wasteful road-building and logging is particularly relevant in the Tongass, where logging costs vastly exceed timber revenues and require unconscionable taxpayer subsidies.

Regards,
Jean Stephenson
docAbstract: The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) is proposing to exempt the Tongass National Forest from the 2001 Roadless Area Conservation Rule, which prohibits tree harvest and road construction/reconstruction within inventoried roadless areas with certain limited exceptions. In addition, the proposed rule would provide an administrative procedure for correcting and modifying inventoried roadless area boundaries on the Chugach National Forest. The USDA invites written comments on the proposed rule and the draft environmental impact statement (DEIS). The proposed rule would not directly authorize any ground-disturbing activities. Substantive comments received during the comment period will be considered in developing the final rule and final environmental impact statement (FEIS). The final rule will be published in the Federal Register.

I am writing to support the No-Action Alternative for the Draft Environmental Impact Statement on the proposed Alaska Roadless Rule, Alternative #1. I support keeping the current Roadless Rule protections in place and intact for the Tongass National Forest. Trumps plan is yet another attack from the Trump administration on Indigenous rights. Alaskan Native communities -- including the Tlingit, Haida, and Tsimshian peoples -- have depended on the Tongass Rainforest for millennia. It is the backbone to their culture, traditions, and communities -- we simply cannot let it disappear.

The Tongass contains some of the largest intact old-growth temperate rainforest in the world, and its value in providing clean water for fish and wildlife habitat is essential to the economic and ecological health of Southeast Alaska. I urge you to keep the federal Roadless Rule intact and current protections in place for national forests in Alaska.

In addition, I strongly object to your plans to reduce and remove protections from our national forests roadless areas. The Roadless Rule is one of the smartest and most popular land management policies the Federal Government has ever adopted. Not only does it preserve some of Americas best fish and wildlife habitat, but it also saves untold millions of taxpayer dollars that might otherwise be spent to subsidize money-losing timber sales. The value of the Roadless Rule in preventing environmentally damaging and economically wasteful road-building and logging is particularly relevant in the Tongass, where logging costs vastly exceed timber revenues and require unconscionable taxpayer subsidies.

Regards,
Eileen Schepers
docAbstract: The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) is proposing to exempt the Tongass National Forest from the 2001 Roadless Area Conservation Rule, which prohibits tree harvest and road construction/reconstruction within inventoried roadless areas with certain limited exceptions. In addition, the proposed rule would provide an administrative procedure for correcting and modifying inventoried roadless area boundaries on the Chugach National Forest. The USDA invites written comments on the proposed rule and the draft environmental impact statement (DEIS). The proposed rule would not directly authorize any ground-disturbing activities. Substantive comments received during the comment period will be considered in developing the final rule and final environmental impact statement (FEIS). The final rule will be published in the Federal Register.

text: Every child deserves a loving home. Do not deprive children of this due to ignorance and or prejudice

My name is Gerri Sainte and Im from Hlen Oaks, NY. Im writing in regard to the published Health and Human Services Grants Regulation (RIN 0991-AC16).

As a black woman with Caribbean roots, I cannot sit by and not question a policy that allows any company to discriminate against consumers while receiving my hard earned tax monies.

My grandmother and two of my cousins were adopted. Without adoption, my family would not exist as I know it. Therefore I understand exactly how important it is that adoption be open to every loving parent, without discrimination. My grandmother was a Buddhist, and the couple who adopted my cousins are agnostics. Their minority religious beliefs or lack thereof didn't harm these loving adoptive families. Religion isn't what makes a family, and child-placing agencies should not be able to impose their religious beliefs on others or to discriminate against religious minorities. Children who don't share the religious beliefs of a child-placing agency should not be denied services because of that, nor should parents that are religious minorities be refused the chance to adopt or care for a child.

This country is supposed to separate church and state. Children deserve loving caring parents. LGBTQ should NOT be discriminated against because of religious beliefs. If they are loving caring people who qualify in every way to be parents they should be given all the same opportunities as everyone else.

My name is Gail Rossitter and Im from Cambridge, Massachusetts. Im writing in regard to the published Health and Human Services Grants Regulation (RIN 0991-AC16).

Discrimination should never be part of tax payer funded programs and Americans should never be looking for ways to make others lives harder. Enacting this proposal would do just that.

Sincerely,
Gail Rossitter

My name is Sandy Rhein and Im from Metairie, Louisiana. Im writing in regard to the published Health and Human Services Grants Regulation (RIN 0991-AC16).

This proposal would permit discrimination against LGBTQ people, religious minorities, and women in programs related to foster care, adoption, HIV and STI prevention, refugee resettlement, elder care programs and more.
The White House has already announced that it will not enforce the existing non-discrimination requirements regarding sexual orientation, gender identity, religion and sex in programs that receive federal funding where the protection isnt statutorily required even before the rule is finalized.
If approved, this would give HHS programs a license to discriminate against LGBTQ and other marginalized groups with tax-payer funds.
It is clear that discrimination has no place in this country, especially in these vital, taxpayer funded programs.

***ADD PERSONAL MESSAGE about why discrimination has no place in HHS programs**

There is already a limited amount of foster and adoptive parents who are willing to take in a child. Allowing this rule will cause that number to decrease even further. I am writing to support the No-Action Alternative for the Draft Environmental Impact Statement on the proposed Alaska Roadless Rule, Alternative #1. I support keeping the current Roadless Rule protections in place and intact for the Tongass National Forest. Trumps plan is yet another attack from the Trump administration on Indigenous rights. Alaskan Native communities -- including the Tlingit, Haida, and Tsimshian peoples -- have depended on the Tongass Rainforest for millennia. It is the backbone to their culture, traditions, and communities -- we simply cannot let it disappear.

The Tongass contains some of the largest intact old-growth temperate rainforest in the world, and its value in providing clean water for fish and wildlife habitat is essential to the economic and ecological health of Southeast Alaska. I urge you to keep the federal Roadless Rule intact and current protections in place for national forests in Alaska.

In addition, I strongly object to your plans to reduce and remove protections from our national forests roadless areas. The Roadless Rule is one of the smartest and most popular land management policies the Federal Government has ever adopted. Not only does it preserve some of Americas best fish and wildlife habitat, but it also saves untold millions of taxpayer dollars that might otherwise be spent to subsidize money-losing timber sales. The value of the Roadless Rule in preventing environmentally damaging and economically wasteful road-building and logging is particularly relevant in the Tongass, where logging costs vastly exceed timber revenues and require unconscionable taxpayer subsidies.

Regards,
Tasha Moore
docAbstract: The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) is proposing to exempt the Tongass National Forest from the 2001 Roadless Area Conservation Rule, which prohibits tree harvest and road construction/reconstruction within inventoried roadless areas with certain limited exceptions. In addition, the proposed rule would provide an administrative procedure for correcting and modifying inventoried roadless area boundaries on the Chugach National Forest. The USDA invites written comments on the proposed rule and the draft environmental impact statement (DEIS). The proposed rule would not directly authorize any ground-disturbing activities. Substantive comments received during the comment period will be considered in developing the final rule and final environmental impact statement (FEIS). The final rule will be published in the Federal Register.

Allowing organizations to become tools of bigoted people to further discriminate under the auspices of the federal government - that represents me! - is bad and wrong. People who want to discriminate and still receive my tax dollars should be ashamed. They are moochers.

My name is Alexandrea Riddell and Im from Great Falls, Virginia. Im writing in regard to the published Health and Human Services Grants Regulation (RIN 0991-AC16).

Our country was founded on the basis of equality. While that vision, was not fully executed to include all groups, we have slowly worked toward a more equal country throughout the past two centuries. Discrimination has no place in our society in present day. As a history teacher, I hope to never have to tell my students how in the 21st century the US government and society still thought it was ok to discriminate against any group. As someone who has friends that are LGBTQ, in religious minorities, and as a woman myself, the idea of this cut in funding and the allowing in discrimination is shameful. Even if I knew none of these groups ( though EVERYONE does), our government should not be attempting to hurt others based on their groups.

Sincerely,
Alexandrea Riddell

My name is Gregg Halkuff and Im from Fuquay-Varina, NC. Im writing in regard to the published Health and Human Services Grants Regulation (RIN 0091-AC16).

Any new regulations that don't protect LGBTQ people, or discriminate against any minority groups or religions should be outright rejected. We have a separation of church and state and the government doesn't get to pick and choose who should be able to discriminate. Vote NO on these hateful and discriminatory regulations.We will vote you out if you continue to follow through on the Pence/Trump method of dividing America or the Make America Great for white Christians bandwagon.

I am writing to support the No-Action Alternative for the Draft Environmental Impact Statement on the proposed Alaska Roadless Rule, Alternative #1. I support keeping the current Roadless Rule protections in place and intact for the Tongass National Forest. Trumps plan is yet another attack from the Trump administration on Indigenous rights. Alaskan Native communities -- including the Tlingit, Haida, and Tsimshian peoples -- have depended on the Tongass Rainforest for millennia. It is the backbone to their culture, traditions, and communities -- we simply cannot let it disappear.

The Tongass contains some of the largest intact old-growth temperate rainforest in the world, and its value in providing clean water for fish and wildlife habitat is essential to the economic and ecological health of Southeast Alaska. I urge you to keep the federal Roadless Rule intact and current protections in place for national forests in Alaska.

In addition, I strongly object to your plans to reduce and remove protections from our national forests roadless areas. The Roadless Rule is one of the smartest and most popular land management policies the Federal Government has ever adopted. Not only does it preserve some of Americas best fish and wildlife habitat, but it also saves untold millions of taxpayer dollars that might otherwise be spent to subsidize money-losing timber sales. The value of the Roadless Rule in preventing environmentally damaging and economically wasteful road-building and logging is particularly relevant in the Tongass, where logging costs vastly exceed timber revenues and require unconscionable taxpayer subsidies.

Regards,
Lance Weyeneth

Substantive comments received during the comment period will be considered in developing the final rule and final environmental impact statement (FEIS). I am writing to support the No-Action Alternative for the Draft Environmental Impact Statement on the proposed Alaska Roadless Rule, Alternative #1. I support keeping the current Roadless Rule protections in place and intact for the Tongass National Forest. Trumps plan is yet another attack from the Trump administration on Indigenous rights. Alaskan Native communities -- including the Tlingit, Haida, and Tsimshian peoples -- have depended on the Tongass Rainforest for millennia. It is the backbone to their culture, traditions, and communities -- we simply cannot let it disappear.

The Tongass contains some of the largest intact old-growth temperate rainforest in the world, and its value in providing clean water for fish and wildlife habitat is essential to the economic and ecological health of Southeast Alaska. I urge you to keep the federal Roadless Rule intact and current protections in place for national forests in Alaska.

In addition, I strongly object to your plans to reduce and remove protections from our national forests roadless areas. The Roadless Rule is one of the smartest and most popular land management policies the Federal Government has ever adopted. Not only does it preserve some of Americas best fish and wildlife habitat, but it also saves untold millions of taxpayer dollars that might otherwise be spent to subsidize money-losing timber sales. The value of the Roadless Rule in preventing environmentally damaging and economically wasteful road-building and logging is particularly relevant in the Tongass, where logging costs vastly exceed timber revenues and require unconscionable taxpayer subsidies.

Regards,
Jane Jackson
docAbstract: The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) is proposing to exempt the Tongass National Forest from the 2001 Roadless Area Conservation Rule, which prohibits tree harvest and road construction/reconstruction within inventoried roadless areas with certain limited exceptions. In addition, the proposed rule would provide an administrative procedure for correcting and modifying inventoried roadless area boundaries on the Chugach National Forest. The USDA invites written comments on the proposed rule and the draft environmental impact statement (DEIS). The proposed rule would not directly authorize any ground-disturbing activities. Substantive comments received during the comment period will be considered in developing the final rule and final environmental impact statement (FEIS). The final rule will be published in the Federal Register.

text:
My name is Michael Gossmanand Im from Pensacola Beach, Florida. Im writing in regard to the published Health and Human Services Grants Regulation (RIN 0091-AC16).

There should never be discrimination in our Government for an reason, ever. All residents and citizens pay taxes. These are the people who need the most help, not the least.

I am writing to support the No-Action Alternative for the Draft Environmental Impact Statement on the proposed Alaska Roadless Rule, Alternative #1. I support keeping the current Roadless Rule protections in place and intact for the Tongass National Forest. Trumps plan is yet another attack from the Trump administration on Indigenous rights. Alaskan Native communities -- including the Tlingit, Haida, and Tsimshian peoples -- have depended on the Tongass Rainforest for millennia. It is the backbone to their culture, traditions, and communities -- we simply cannot let it disappear.

The Tongass contains some of the largest intact old-growth temperate rainforest in the world, and its value in providing clean water for fish and wildlife habitat is essential to the economic and ecological health of Southeast Alaska. I urge you to keep the federal Roadless Rule intact and current protections in place for national forests in Alaska.

In addition, I strongly object to your plans to reduce and remove protections from our national forests roadless areas. The Roadless Rule is one of the smartest and most popular land management policies the Federal Government has ever adopted. Not only does it preserve some of Americas best fish and wildlife habitat, but it also saves untold millions of taxpayer dollars that might otherwise be spent to subsidize money-losing timber sales. The value of the Roadless Rule in preventing environmentally damaging and economically wasteful road-building and logging is particularly relevant in the Tongass, where logging costs vastly exceed timber revenues and require unconscionable taxpayer subsidies.

Regards,
Robert Taylor

I am writing to support the No-Action Alternative for the Draft Environmental Impact Statement on the proposed Alaska Roadless Rule, Alternative #1. I support keeping the current Roadless Rule protections in place and intact for the Tongass National Forest. Trumps plan is yet another attack from the Trump administration on Indigenous rights. Alaskan Native communities -- including the Tlingit, Haida, and Tsimshian peoples -- have depended on the Tongass Rainforest for millennia. It is the backbone to their culture, traditions, and communities -- we simply cannot let it disappear.

The Tongass contains some of the largest intact old-growth temperate rainforest in the world, and its value in providing clean water for fish and wildlife habitat is essential to the economic and ecological health of Southeast Alaska. I urge you to keep the federal Roadless Rule intact and current protections in place for national forests in Alaska.

In addition, I strongly object to your plans to reduce and remove protections from our national forests roadless areas. The Roadless Rule is one of the smartest and most popular land management policies the Federal Government has ever adopted. Not only does it preserve some of Americas best fish and wildlife habitat, but it also saves untold millions of taxpayer dollars that might otherwise be spent to subsidize money-losing timber sales. The value of the Roadless Rule in preventing environmentally damaging and economically wasteful road-building and logging is particularly relevant in the Tongass, where logging costs vastly exceed timber revenues and require unconscionable taxpayer subsidies.
This matters tremendously to me and I urge your prompt attention

Regards,
Lydia Peter
docAbstract: The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) is proposing to exempt the Tongass National Forest from the 2001 Roadless Area Conservation Rule, which prohibits tree harvest and road construction/reconstruction within inventoried roadless areas with certain limited exceptions. In addition, the proposed rule would provide an administrative procedure for correcting and modifying inventoried roadless area boundaries on the Chugach National Forest. The USDA invites written comments on the proposed rule and the draft environmental impact statement (DEIS). The proposed rule would not directly authorize any ground-disturbing activities. Substantive comments received during the comment period will be considered in developing the final rule and final environmental impact statement (FEIS). The final rule will be published in the Federal Register.

I am writing to support the No-Action Alternative for the Draft Environmental Impact Statement on the proposed Alaska Roadless Rule, Alternative #1. I support keeping the current Roadless Rule protections in place and intact for the Tongass National Forest. Trumps plan is yet another attack from the Trump administration on Indigenous rights. Alaskan Native communities -- including the Tlingit, Haida, and Tsimshian peoples -- have depended on the Tongass Rainforest for millennia. It is the backbone to their culture, traditions, and communities -- we simply cannot let it disappear.

The Tongass contains some of the largest intact old-growth temperate rainforest in the world, and its value in providing clean water for fish and wildlife habitat is essential to the economic and ecological health of Southeast Alaska. I urge you to keep the federal Roadless Rule intact and current protections in place for national forests in Alaska.

In addition, I strongly object to your plans to reduce and remove protections from our national forests roadless areas. The Roadless Rule is one of the smartest and most popular land management policies the Federal Government has ever adopted. Not only does it preserve some of Americas best fish and wildlife habitat, but it also saves untold millions of taxpayer dollars that might otherwise be spent to subsidize money-losing timber sales. The value of the Roadless Rule in preventing environmentally damaging and economically wasteful road-building and logging is particularly relevant in the Tongass, where logging costs vastly exceed timber revenues and require unconscionable taxpayer subsidies.

Regards,
Aaron Ortiz

I am writing to support the No-Action Alternative for the Draft Environmental Impact Statement on the proposed Alaska Roadless Rule, Alternative #1. I support keeping the current Roadless Rule protections in place and intact for the Tongass National Forest. Trumps plan is yet another attack from the Trump administration on Indigenous rights. Alaskan Native communities -- including the Tlingit, Haida, and Tsimshian peoples -- have depended on the Tongass Rainforest for millennia. It is the backbone to their culture, traditions, and communities -- we simply cannot let it disappear.

The Tongass contains some of the largest intact old-growth temperate rainforest in the world, and its value in providing clean water for fish and wildlife habitat is essential to the economic and ecological health of Southeast Alaska. I urge you to keep the federal Roadless Rule intact and current protections in place for national forests in Alaska.

In addition, I strongly object to your plans to reduce and remove protections from our national forests roadless areas. The Roadless Rule is one of the smartest and most popular land management policies the Federal Government has ever adopted. Not only does it preserve some of Americas best fish and wildlife habitat, but it also saves untold millions of taxpayer dollars that might otherwise be spent to subsidize money-losing timber sales. The value of the Roadless Rule in preventing environmentally damaging and economically wasteful road-building and logging is particularly relevant in the Tongass, where logging costs vastly exceed timber revenues and require unconscionable taxpayer subsidies.

Regards,
Steve Balkin
docAbstract: The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) is proposing to exempt the Tongass National Forest from the 2001 Roadless Area Conservation Rule, which prohibits tree harvest and road construction/reconstruction within inventoried roadless areas with certain limited exceptions. In addition, the proposed rule would provide an administrative procedure for correcting and modifying inventoried roadless area boundaries on the Chugach National Forest. The USDA invites written comments on the proposed rule and the draft environmental impact statement (DEIS). The proposed rule would not directly authorize any ground-disturbing activities. Substantive comments received during the comment period will be considered in developing the final rule and final environmental impact statement (FEIS). The final rule will be published in the Federal Register.

text:
To whom it may concern:

I strongly oppose the proposed rule from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (RIN 0991-AC16). This rule eliminates protections against discrimination in HHS-funded programs. Agencies and programs that serve the public will be allowed to deny services to eligible people. This rule will cause harm, especially to people who are LGBTQ, women, and people of minority faiths.

That means:

People who need medical care could be turned away from a community health center because of their sexual orientation.
An agency providing foster care services could keep a child in a group home rather than place them with qualified same-sex parents.
After-school programs. like the ones my children are enrolled in, could refuse to serve transgender youth.

Government agencies should not be condoning discrimination nor using taxpayer dollars to support discrimination. Organizations that receive government funds that are designed specifically to serve the public must not be permitted to show prejudice when deciding whom they will serve. I urge HHS to immediately withdraw this misguided proposal.

Sincerely,
Johanna

text:
I am writing to support the No-Action Alternative for the Draft Environmental Impact Statement on the proposed Alaska Roadless Rule, Alternative #1. I support keeping the current Roadless Rule protections in place and intact for the Tongass National Forest. Trumps plan is yet another attack from the Trump administration on Indigenous rights. Alaskan Native communities -- including the Tlingit, Haida, and Tsimshian peoples -- have depended on the Tongass Rainforest for millennia. It is the backbone to their culture, traditions, and communities -- we simply cannot let it disappear.

The Tongass contains some of the largest intact old-growth temperate rainforest in the world, and its value in providing clean water for fish and wildlife habitat is essential to the economic and ecological health of Southeast Alaska. I urge you to keep the federal Roadless Rule intact and current protections in place for national forests in Alaska.

In addition, I strongly object to your plans to reduce and remove protections from our national forests roadless areas. The Roadless Rule is one of the smartest and most popular land management policies the Federal Government has ever adopted. Not only does it preserve some of Americas best fish and wildlife habitat, but it also saves untold millions of taxpayer dollars that might otherwise be spent to subsidize money-losing timber sales. The value of the Roadless Rule in preventing environmentally damaging and economically wasteful road-building and logging is particularly relevant in the Tongass, where logging costs vastly exceed timber revenues and require unconscionable taxpayer subsidies.

Regards,
Justine Friend
label: pos
docAbstract: The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) is proposing to exempt the Tongass National Forest from the 2001 Roadless Area Conservation Rule, which prohibits tree harvest and road construction/reconstruction within inventoried roadless areas with certain limited exceptions. In addition, the proposed rule would provide an administrative procedure for correcting and modifying inventoried roadless area boundaries on the Chugach National Forest. The USDA invites written comments on the proposed rule and the draft environmental impact statement (DEIS). The proposed rule would not directly authorize any ground-disturbing activities. Substantive comments received during the comment period will be considered in developing the final rule and final environmental impact statement (FEIS). The final rule will be published in the Federal Register.
